text.title: And in the first year of Cyrus, the king of Persia:

pasuk.text: This book is arranged as a continuation of the Book of Daniel, as is explained in Baba Bathra (15a), and the word וּבְשְׁנַת refers back from this [book] to that one, for it is stated in Daniel (9:2): “In the first year of his reign, I, Daniel, contemplated the calculations of the number of the years that the word of the Lord had come to Jeremiah the prophet from the destruction of Jerusalem, seventy years.” And so the entire chapter proceeds to relate [the story] of the destruction of the Temple, the time of the Babylonian exile, and his confession, in which he confessed Israel’s sin. The beginning of this book is as follows: After Belshazzar was assassinated, Darius the Mede reigned, as it says (Dan. 6:1): “And Darius the Mede received the kingdom etc.” and after Darius’ death, this Cyrus, the king of Persia, reigned, and in the first year of his reign, the seventy years for the remembrance of the Babylonian exile, [counting] from the day that Jehoiakim was exiled, were completed, as it says (Jer. 29: 10): “At the completion of seventy years of Babylon, I will remember you etc.” When Israel returned from the Babylonian exile to the land of Israel, in that year, in the first year of Cyrus, Israel laid the foundation of the Temple, and the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin slandered them to Cyrus, the king of Persia, and he commanded [them] to curtail the work, no longer to build the edifice of the Temple; and the Israelites were idle, for they did not build the Temple during the entire reign of Cyrus and Ahasuerus, who succeeded him, until the second year of Darius, the son of Ahasuerus, the king of Persia, who was Darius, the son of Esther. And in the second year of his reign, they began building the Temple until the building was completed. And from the first year of Cyrus until the second year of Darius, the son of Ahasuerus the king of Persia, in whose days the Temple was built, were eighteen years, to fulfill what was said (Dan. 9:2): “from the destruction of Jerusalem, seventy years etc.” And now, in the second year of Darius, seventy years had elapsed since the destruction of Jerusalem; [i.e.,] the destruction of the Temple, when Zedekiah was exiled. From the exile of Jehoiakim until the exile of Zedekiah, when the Temple was destroyed, were eighteen years, and now in the first year of Cyrus, the king of Persia, seventy years since the exile of Jehoiakim, when Israel was exiled to Babylon, were completed, and thereby the verse that states (Jer. 29:10): “for at the completion of seventy years of Babylon I will remember you etc.” was fulfilled. And this is the remembrance, that Israel returned to their soil and built the foundation of the building of the Temple, although it was not yet completed. We find that there were fifty- two years from the exile of Zedekiah, when the Temple was destroyed, until the first year of Cyrus, the king of Persia; and eighteen years after the first year of Cyrus, which is the second year of Darius, when Israel commenced to build the edifice, and they completed it. This is proven in Seder Olam (ch. 29), in Tractate Megillah (11b) and in this book, as I explained.

text.title: at the completion of the word of the Lord from the mouth of Jeremiah:

pasuk.text: at the time that the word of the Holy One, blessed be He, which Jeremiah spoke, was completed, as it says (Jer. 29:10): “for at the completion of seventy years of Babylon etc.”
the will.
He proclaimed a proclamation throughout his kingdom.
And he also sent his letter throughout his kingdom about this matter.
And so he said to them in his proclamation that he proclaimed and in his epistle that he sent throughout his kingdom.

text.title: So said Cyrus, the king of Persia… delivered to me:

pasuk.text: that I am the king and ruler over all the kingdoms.

He commanded me through Isaiah the prophet to build for Him the Temple in Jerusalem, as it says in the Book of Isaiah (44:28): “Who says to Cyrus, ‘He is My shepherd, and all My desire he shall fulfill,’ and to say to Jerusalem, ‘It shall be built, and the Temple shall be founded.’” (ibid. 45:1): “So said the Lord to His anointed one, to Cyrus, whose right hand I held….” And this prophecy was already stated by lsaiah.

text.title: in Jerusalem, which is in Judea:

pasuk.text: whch is in the province of Judea.

So did he announce and write to all the kingdoms, “Who is among you of all His people,” [i.e., of the people] of the Holy One, blessed be He, may the Holy One, blessed be He, be at his assistance, and let him ascend to build His house that is in Jerusalem.
and every Jew who remains in his place, who cannot ascend because he has no money.

I command the people of his place to provide him and help him with silver, gold, possessions and cattle, in order that he be able to ascend to Jerusalem with the donation that the people of his place will donate for the building of the Temple, for also among the nations there were some who contributed donations to the building of the Temple.

text.title: to the House of God, which is in Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: From “So said Cyrus” until here is the proclamation and the message of the written epistle.
the heads of the families of the tribes of Judah and Benjamin.
They ascended to Jerusalem to build the Temple with all those whom God inspired to ascend and to build the Temple.
And all the nations who were Israel’s neighbors assisted and strengthened the hands of the Jews with gold and silver and all these gifts in order that they be able to ascend to Jerusalem.
All this the neighbors of the Jews did, besides what they [the Jews] themselves donated for the building of the Temple.

text.title: and had placed them in the temple of his god:

pasuk.text: that Nebuchadnezzar had placed in the temple of his pagan deity.

text.title: by the hand of Mithderath the treasurer:

pasuk.text: such was the name of Cyrus’s treasurer, and Cyrus commanded [him] to take them out.

This treasurer counted them and delivered them to Sheshbazzar, so that he would carry them and transport them to Jerusalem. Our Rabbis said: “Sheshbazzar is identical with Daniel, and why was he called Sheshbazzar? Because he endured six troubles (שֵּׁשּׁ צָרוֹת).”
He is the prince of the tribe of Judah.
of the vessels of the House of the Lord.
Heb. אֲגַרְטְלֵי. They are kinds of vessels.

Heb. מַחֲלָפִים. They are knives, and this expression refers to the chamber of the knives (בֵּית הַחֲלִיפוֹת). Because they would deposit the knives therein, it was called the chamber of the depository of the knives (לִשְּׁכַּת בֵּית הַחֲלִיפוֹת).

Heb. כְּפוֹרֵי, bowls, and they were called כְּפוֹרֵי from an expression of wiping, like (Bava Mezia 24b): “who wiped (דְּכָפַר) his hands on his neighbor’s cloak,” because the one who would receive the blood in a bowl would wipe the squirtings of the blood that splattered on his hand on the rim of the bowl.
Heb. מִשְּׁנִים, secondary ones, other vessels of another kind.
Now he totals the sum of those counted and those who were not counted all into one number, but the important ones he counts.

text.title: when the exiles were brought up:

pasuk.text: Heb. הֵעָלוֹת, [a passive] expression.

text.title: And these are the people of the province:

pasuk.text: These are the Children of Israel who are from the province of the land of Israel, who are now coming up to Jerusalem from the captivity that is in the exile.
And now they returned to Jerusalem.
And the people of Judea returned, each one to his city.
these people of the province, in the beginning, when they went into exile from Israel to Babylon with Zerubbabel etc.

Heb. מִסְפָּר. [This word appears twice in this verse.] In the first one, the “pay” is vowelized with a “kamatz,” and it is the name of a man; in the second, the “pay” is vowelized with a “pattah” , and it is the construct state, [meaning the number of].

text.title: the important men of the people of Israel:

pasuk.text: These were the great and important people, and the others followed them. Therefore, they were counted after them separately.

There are some in the chapter for whom the father’s name is used for the family name [surname] and there are some who are called by the name of their place, i.e., “the children of such-and-such a place.”

text.title: The priests: the children of Jedaiah:

pasuk.text: Until here, he counted the children of Judah and Benjamin, and from now on he counts the priests and the Levites, as he says above (1:5): “So the heads of the families of Judah and Benjamin and the priests and the Levites arose….”
The Levites who were singers, and likewise, the gatekeepers are Levites who were gatekeepers of the gates of the Temple.
Now he counts those Nethinim who were woodcutters and water-drawers for the congregation, and from there they derived their livelihood.

text.title: and the children of Solomon’s slaves:

pasuk.text: King Solomon had slaves, and these children were of their descendants.

text.title: And these were the ones who ascended from Tel-Mela, etc.:

pasuk.text: And what incident happened to them? They could not tell….
[i.e., the children] of their fathers, because they lost their genealogical records and did not know if they were Israelites.
They too are included in “these were the ones who ascended from Tel- Melah.”
Each one of the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite took a wife.

text.title: and was called by their name:

pasuk.text: And the name of Barzillai was called on their name because they took of his daughters.
referring to the priests, who had to trace their lineage with that record, and who could not find the record of their lineage.
Heb. וַיְגאַלוּ, for they were defiled and purged from the priesthood that they should no longer perform the service with the remaining priests, because their genealogical record was not found.

That is Nehemiah, the son of Hachaliah (Neh. 8:9), and our Rabbis said (Yerushalmi Kid. 4:1) that he was named Hattirshatha because the Sages permitted him (הָתֵּר) to drink (שָּׁתָּא) wine of gentiles because he was the king’s butler.
sin-offerings and guilt-offerings, like the other priests.

like a person who says to his friend, “Until the Messiah comes, this matter will not come about.” I cannot interpret it to mean: until a priest arises for the Urim and Tumim in the Second Temple, because we find in Yoma, chapter 1 (21b) that the Urim and Tumim were missing in the Second Temple.

When they were all together with the priests, the Levites and the Nethinim, they amounted to this number; and the Children of Israel counted above were of the tribe of Judah and Benjamin, and those missing from this number, which you will not find above, were of the other tribes. So it is explained in Seder Olam (ch. 29): “ ‘The entire congregation together was forty-two thousand etc.’ But if you add them up, they are only thirty thousand. Where are the thirteen thousand? They ascended from the other tribes.”

text.title: Besides their slaves and their bondwomen:

pasuk.text: who were not included in the congregation.

text.title: and they had two hundred male and female singers:

pasuk.text: because they were going up joyfully from Babylon to the land of Israel, they required male and female singers in order that they should stroll among them in their great joy.
They were donating toward the building of the Temple.
according to their ability and their money.
Heb. דַּרְכְּמוֹנִים, the name of a golden coin.
in which to serve.
Heb. וַיִגַע like וְהִגִיעַ, it reached.
That is the month of Tishri, and the Children of Israel who were in the cities, what did they do? They all gathered as one to Jerusalem.

text.title: And they set the altar on its bases:

pasuk.text: in order to offer up sacrifices upon it, because they were afraid of the peoples of the land, lest they taunt them and lest they slander them to the king. And they built the altar to offer up burnt offerings upon it, in order that the peoples hear and understand the matter, that they did it with the sanction of the king and therefore they would hesitate to taunt them about the building of the Temple.

text.title: for the morning and for the evening:

pasuk.text: the daily sacrifice of the morning and the daily sacrifice of twilight.

text.title: and the burnt offering of each day in its day, in the number:

pasuk.text: the sacrifices of the Festivals in their number, according to their ordinance.
And after Succoth they would offer up sacrifices every day, for the morning and for the evening.
lit. and for the months. And at the beginning of the months they would offer up the sacrifices of the New Moon.

text.title: and for all the appointed seasons of the Lord:

pasuk.text: and for the rest of the appointed seasons of their sacrifices.

text.title: and for everyone who willingly offered:

pasuk.text: And for all those who willingly offered their free-will offerings, the priests would accept them to sacrifice them, and from the first day of Tishri they commenced to offer up sacrifices, but the foundation of the Temple was not yet built.

text.title: to the Zidonians and to the Tyrians:

pasuk.text: the people of Tyre and Zidon, who were the artisans who built the Temple.
By way of the sea they would bring them.

Heb. כְּרִשְׁיוֹן as the sanction of the king was upon them to build the Temple. כְּרִשְׁיוֹן is an expression of permission (רְשּׁוּת) derived from רשּׁה; since from אבה to want, he says [i.e., derives] אֶבְיוֹן, a needy person; and from צבה, to desire, צִבְיוֹן, desire; and from חזה to see, חִזָיוֹן, a vision; and from רעה, רַעְיוֹן, thought; from חבה, חֶבְיוֹן, hiding; and from רשּׁה, he says רְשּׁוּת, permission; like from, ענה, עֱנוּת, affliction; and from שּׁבה, שְּׁבוּת, captivity; and from ראה, רְאוּת, a sight; and from זנה, זְנוּת, harlotry. The result is that רְשּׁוּת and רִשְׁיוֹן are derived from the same root according to the gauge of grammar, and they are the same expression. Menahem, (p. 34) however, associated it with (Ps. 21: 3): “and the speech of his lips (וַאֲרֶשֶּׁת),” but he was not exact with its root. Nevertheless, these two manners [of defining words] are close to each other in their meanings.
That is the month of Iyar.
all those who came from the captivity to Jerusalem.
They stationed the Levite singers to harmonize and to recite a song before the builders at the time of the building of the foundation of the Temple.
Heb. לְנַצֵחַ. These two expressions of נִצוּחַ are harmonies of song, like (Ps. 4:1): “To the conductor (לַּמְנַצֵחַ), a song of David.”
They stood and recited the song together around the ones who did the work of the foundation of the Temple.

וְיִסְדוּ This is the strong conjugation of יְסוֹד, like (Ezek. 25:4): “and they will settle (וְיִשְּׁבוּ) their palaces.” Just as וְיִשְּׁבוּ is derived from ישּׁב so is וְיִסְדוּ derived from יסד, and their meaning is, וְיִסְדוּ וְיִשְּׁבוּ in the intensive conjugation with two “yud” s, one for the [continuous] action and one for the radical, and their meaning is that they were laying the foundation, they were settling.

text.title: And the builders laid the foundation:

pasuk.text: And the builders were laying the foundation [see above] of the Temple of the Lord at the time [that] they were harmonizing in their song, and they stationed the priests attired with elegant garments with trumpets in their hands to sound them.

text.title: and the Levites the sons of Asaph:

pasuk.text: were the singers.
Heb. בַּמְצִלְתַּיִם, like (Ps. 150:9): “with loud sounding cymbals (בְּצִלְצְלֵי שָּׁמַע).” They are musical instruments.
for they were harmonizing and singing songs of David, the king of Israel.
Heb. וַיַעֲנוּ, an expression of raising the voice in song, like (Exod. 15:21): “And Miriam raised her voice in song to them.”
and with thanksgivings.
to give thanks to the Lord.
the rest of the people of Israel.
They acted with all these rejoicings because of the building of the foundation, which was laid in the House of the Lord.
Heb. בְּיָסְדוֹ, with its foundation. With the noun of יוֹסֶד and from יסד, he says בְּיָסְדוֹ, like from חדֶשּׁ, בְּחָדְשּׁוֹ, and from קדֶשּׁ, בְּקָדְשּׁוֹ.
When they would see the building of this Temple, they would weep because they remembered the large building of the First Temple.
who had not seen the building of the First Temple, were rejoicing and shouting for joy with a loud voice, out of their great joy that they had emerged from their exile.

text.title: And the people did not recognize:

pasuk.text: Those listeners did not recognize the voice of the shout of joy, because of the voice of the people’s weeping, for the rejoicing people were shouting with a great shout, and the voice of weeping was heard farther and farther away.

text.title: the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin:

pasuk.text: They are the nations whom Sannecherib settled in the land Israel, as it says (II Kings 17: 24): “And the king of Assyria brought [people] from Babylonia and from Cuthah and from Avvah and from Hamath and from Sepharvaim, and he settled them in the cities of Samaria instead of the Children of Israel.”

text.title: and said to them, “Let us build with you…”:

pasuk.text: They said this in order that through them the work of the Temple should be disrupted, that they should build no more.

text.title: since the days of Esarhaddon the king of Assyria:

pasuk.text: the son of Sannecherib, for after Sannecherib settled them there, as it says (II Kings 29:37, Isa. 37:38): “And he was prostrating himself in the temple of Nisroch his god, and Adramelech and Sharezer, his sons, slew him by the sword etc., and his son Esarhaddon reigned in his stead.”
Heb. כִּי, but we alone shall build. This כִּי serves in place of אֶלָּא, but.
They are the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin.
to disrupt them from their work.
Heb. לִבְנוֹת, lit. to build, and so (Gen. 41:49): “until one ceased to count (לִסְפֹּר).”
Heb. וְסֹכְרִים. This is written with a “sammech,” but its meaning is as though it was written with a “sin,” [meaning] that they would hire advisors to disrupt the work.
the reign of Cyrus and the reign of Ahasuerus, who reigned after Cyrus, until the second year of Darius, who reigned after Ahasuerus, the work was stopped.

text.title: And in the reign of Ahasuerus:

pasuk.text: who reigned after Cyrus; he is the Ahasuerus who took Esther.
not to build the Temple.

text.title: against the dwellers of Judea and Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: to inform on them and to chide them not to build the Temple.

text.title: And in the days of Artaxerxes:

pasuk.text: He is Cyrus, the king of Persia. The numerical value of the letters of כּרֶשּׁ equal the numerical value of the letters of דָּרְיָוֶשּׁ : [כ = 20; ר = 200; שּׁ = 300; total = 520. ד = 4; ר = 200; י = 10; 520 ו = 6; שּׁ = 300; total = 520.] And so we learned in Tractate Rosh Hashanah (3b): “The same one is Cyrus, who is Darius, who is Artaxerxes.” [He was called Cyrus כּרֶשּׁ because he was a worthy (כָּשֵּׁר) king; Artaxerxes, because of the kingdom, and in Seder Olam (ch. 30): “Darius was Artaxerxes (אַרְתַּחְשַּׁשְּׁתָּא), and the entire kingdom was called Artaxerxes, etc.” [meaning that all the kings were called Artaxerxes].
wrote his letter with words of peace.
This is the name of a man, one of the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin.

text.title: and the rest of his colleagues:

pasuk.text: Heb. כְּנָותָיו, his companies and his societies.
[as translated,] to Artaxerxes.

text.title: and the script of the epistle:

pasuk.text: Heb. וּכְתָב הַנִשְּׁתְּוָן.
in Aramaic characters.
The script was explained in the Aramaic language.
Rehum was the secretary and the master of words to compose the epistle.

And Shimshai was the scribe: he is Shimshai the son of Haman. So it is customary to mention the scribe and the secretary together because they need each other; one composes and dictates, and the scribe writes, as it says (I Kings 4: 3): “Eliphoreph and Ahiah, the sons of Shisha, scribes, Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahlud, the secretary,” and in another place it says (Isa. 36:22): “And Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah etc. and Shebna the scribe, and Joah, the son of Asaph the secretary, came.”
These two, Rehum and Shimshai, wrote the letter as Mithredath Tabeel had commanded them, and they all were dwellers of the cities of Samaria.
about the building of the Temple, which is in Jerusalem.
Aram. כְּנֵמָא, as is stated, and that is similar to the expression of the Gemara: “as we wish to say further.”
Aram. אֱדַיִן, equivalent to the Hebrew אָז.
the name of a man.
Aram. בְּעֵל טְעֵם secretary and master of words.
All these are names of nations whom Sennacherib repatriated in the cities of Samaria.
They are the Persians whom Sennacherib settled in the cities of Samaria.
They are the people of Erech, as it says (Gen. 10:10): “and Erech and Accad and Calneh.”
the people of Babylon.
the people of Shushan, the capital.
the people of Elam. Sennacherib settled all of these peoples in the land of Israel, and all of them were settling and concurring with the commission of this letter.

text.title: And the rest of the nations:

pasuk.text: and the rest of the nations that Sennacherib exiled; they have all concurred.
Sennacherib.
for he was a great and honored king, as it says (Isa. 36:4): “So has the great king, the king of Assyria, said.”
in the cities surrounding Samaria.

text.title: and the rest of the other side of the river:

pasuk.text: and the rest of the nations that are on the other side of the river; because the river Euphrates intervenes between the land of Israel and Babylon, those nations that are in Israel are on the opposite side of the river of those found in Babylon.
a name of a place; and all the people of Ke’eneth have concurred with the commission of this letter.

text.title: This is the meaning of the letter:

pasuk.text: and this is the interpretation of the letter.
Aram. פַּרְשֶּׁגֶן like (Esther 3:14): "The meaning of (פַּתְשֶּׁגֶן) the writ.
[as translated,] that they sent to him.
[as translated,] to Artaxerxes.

text.title: Your servants are the people of the other side of the river and Ke’eneth:

pasuk.text: The people of the other side of the river and the people of Ke’eneth are your servants. All the nations counted here are included in this generalization, for they were all on the side of the land of Israel, which is on the opposite side of the river of those dwelling in Babylon, and this is the beginning of the letter: “Your servants are the people of the other side of the river etc.” until, “… you will have no part.”

text.title: Let it be known to the king:

pasuk.text: Let it be a known thing to the king.
that the Jews who ascended from you upon us have come to Jerusalem.

text.title: the rebellious and sinful city they are building:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] a rebellious and sinful city they are building.
[as translated,] the walls they have completed.
[as translated,] and the walls.
Aram. יָחִיטוּ, an expression of a thread, like (Gen. 14:23): “not from a thread, (מִחוּטּ) ,” for they are “sewing” and joining the walls one to another.
Now let it be known to the king.

text.title: that if this city is built:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] that if this city is built.
[as translated,] this.
[as translated,] and the walls are founded.

text.title: the king’s due, the head tax, or the meal tax:

pasuk.text: They are types of taxes and the money for the head taxes.
They will no longer pay taxes.

text.title: and the tax of the kings will suffer:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] and the tax of the kings will suffer, for they will no longer give tax to the kings.

text.title: Now in view of this, that we wish to destroy the Temple:

pasuk.text: Now in view of this matter, that we wish to implement the destruction of the Temple. דִי מְלַח is an expression of destruction and desolation, like Jer. 17:6): “barren (מְלֵחָה) land that is uninhabitable.”
We wish to demolish and to destroy.
Aram. מַלְכָּא וְעַרְוַת, lit. and the king’s nakedness.
Aram. לָא אַרִי, it is improper for us to see. אַרִי means proper, like “Is it proper (אַרִי) or improper (לָא אַרִי) ?” in Tractate Succah (44b).
therefore we have sent and notified the king.
that a seeker should search and seek in the annals of your fathers, the first kings.
And you will find in the annals, and you will know that this city is a rebellious city, and it injures the kings and the countries.

text.title: and they have made rebellion in its midst:

pasuk.text: And its inhabitants were making rebellion in its midst, for Israel would rebel against the kings of the nations.
Aram. מִן יוֹמָת עָלְמָא, from days of yore. Since ancient times, it has been their custom to rebel against the kings of the nations.
Because of this, this city was destroyed.

text.title: We make known to the king:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] we make known to the king.
that if this city is built, and its walls are founded.
In view of this and because of this, you will have no part in the entire other side of the river, because Israel will rebel against you and take everything out of your hands.

text.title: in the other side of the river:

pasuk.text: That is the entire area of the side of Israel, which is on the other side of the river of those who are in Babylon.
Aram. מַלְכָּא פִּתְגָּמָא שְּׁלַח

to Rehum the secretary, and Shimshai the scribe, and to the rest of their companies, who dwelt in the cities of Samaria, and to the rest of the nations who were on the other side of the river of the side of the land of Israel.
They are places, like “and Ke’eneth.” Sometimes he calls it this and sometimes that.
The writ of the letter that you sent to us was explained and read before me.
And the order was given by me, the matter of a command that I commanded.

And they searched in the annals of the kings and found written that this city, from days of yore, would raise itself up and exalt itself over all the kings of the nations, and rebellion and disobedience were committed there to rebel against the kings of the nations.

and mighty kings were in Jerusalem who were the rulers and governors over the entire side of the river on the side of Israel, as it says regarding Solomon (I Kings 5:4): “For he had dominion over all this side of the river, etc.” And taxes and the head tax were given to them, for the nations paid them tribute.

Now give out a word to announce in the land to stop these men, the Children of Israel, from the work, and the city of Jerusalem shall not be built until orders are given with my knowledge and my authorization.

text.title: And beware of committing an error:

pasuk.text: And you shall beware of committing any postponement or error. שָּׁלוּ is desto(u)rber in Old French, to violate.
[as translated,] of committing in this manner.
Why should the act of destruction in this city increase to injure the kings? Until here is Cyrus’ reply, which he sent back.
[as translated,] then.
Since the interpretation of the writ of the letter of Artaxerxes the king-he is Cyrus-this incident took place.

for the writ of this letter was read before Rehum and Shimshai and their companies, and they went with speed and haste to Jerusalem, to the Jews, and stopped them with force and might from continuing the construction of the edifice.
Aram. עַל יְהוּדָיֵא, lit. On the Jews.
Aram. הִמוֹ, equivalent to הֵם.

Then the work of the building of the House of God, which was in Jerusalem, was suspended until the second year of Darius, the king of Persia; for after Cyrus, Ahasuerus, who married Esther, reigned, and after Ahasuerus, Darius, the son of Ahasuerus, who was the son of Esther, reigned. And from the first year of Cyrus, the king of Persia, until the second year of Darius were eighteen years, which completed the seventy years from the destruction of Jerusalem. For from the destruction of the Temple, when Zedekiah was exiled, until the first year of Cyrus, were fifty-two years, as is explained in Seder Olam (ch. 29). There were then eighteen years from the first year of Cyrus until the second year of Darius, totaling a complete seventy years, and in the second year of Darius they commenced to build the Temple until they completed it.

And now in the second year of Darius, there came a prophecy to Haggai and Zechariah, the prophets to the Jews who were in the land of Judea and in Jerusalem, in the Name of the God of Israel to them, to build the edifice of the Temple without the authorization of King Darius.
Aram. עָל יְהוּדָיֵא lit. On the Jews.
Aram. עֲלֵיהוֹן, lit. on them.
[as translated,] then.
They began to build the House of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is in Jerusalem, and with them were the prophets of the Holy One, blessed be He, helping and assisting them.

text.title: At that time, there came upon them:

pasuk.text: At that time, there came upon them these adversaries of Judah and Benjamin to accuse and to slander them regarding the matter of the building.

text.title: the governor of the other side of the river:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] the governor of the other side of the river.
[as translated,] and their companies.

text.title: and so they said to them:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] and so they said to them.
Who ordered you, regarding the matter of building the Temple?
Aram. וְאֻשַּׁרְנָא, and to found these walls, like (4:12): “and the walls (וְאֻשַּׁיָא) they have joined,” the building of walls of bricks (לְבֵנִים) so did Menahem (p. 36) associate it.
[as translated,] then.
[as translated,] as we will say.
Those adversaries of Judah and Benjamin said to them [i.e.,] to Israel.
What are the names of the men?
who are building this building.

text.title: And the eye of their God:

pasuk.text: And the eye of the Holy One, blessed be He, Who is their God, was on the elders of the Jews to upraise them (sic) in the work of the building.

text.title: and they did not stop them:

pasuk.text: And they did not stop the builders.

text.title: until the matter came to Darius:

pasuk.text: And the elders of the Jews answered a word to those adversaries that they should not stop the building until the matter would go to King Darius.
And then the Jews would answer the writ of the letter concerning this, concerning Darius’ reply.
the interpretation of the text of the letter.
[as translated,] and his companies.
They are one nation that was in their companies.
Aram. מַלְכָּא עַל דָּרְיָוֶשּׁ, lit. on King Darius.
Aram. עֲלוֹהִי, lit. on him.

text.title: and so was written in it:

pasuk.text: and so was written in the letter.
All peace shall be his.

text.title: Let it be known to the king:

pasuk.text: Let it be a known thing to the king.
that we went to the land of the province of Judea, to the House of the great God.
And it, the House, is built.
Aram. גְּלָּל (marmre in Old French), marble.

text.title: and wood is laid in the walls:

pasuk.text: And wood is placed in the walls to reinforce the building in order that it endure for a long time.
Aram. אָסְפַּרְנָא מִתְעַבְדָה, was done quickly. אָסְפַּרְנָא is (espleytosement in Old French), rapidly.
Aram. וּמַצְלַח בְּיֶדְהם. And this work was successful in their hands.
When we saw the building, we asked these elders.

text.title: as follows we said to them:

pasuk.text: As we will say immediately following, we said to them.
Who issued to you the authorization to build this house and to found these walls?
the building of a wall of bricks.
We also asked them the names of the builders, the heads of the construction, in order to let you know.
that we should write to you the names of the men.
in whose counsel and authorization they arose to build the House.
Aram. וּכְנֵמָא, as we shall state the matter.
They answered us a word.
We are the servants of the God of the heavens and the earth.

text.title: and we are building the House:

pasuk.text: And we are building the House that was built many years ago.

text.title: and a great king of Israel:

pasuk.text: And a great king that Israel had, viz. King Solomon, built it and founded it.
But now, since our forefathers angered the God of the heavens, He delivered them into the hands of the Chaldean king of Babylon, and he destroyed this House and exiled the people to Babylon.
But in the first year of Cyrus, king of Babylon, Cyrus issued a command to build the House.

the holy vessels of silver and gold, which Nebuchadnezzar had taken out of the Temple that is in Jerusalem and brought to his temple that is in Babylon. Cyrus took them out of the temple of the king of Babylon and delivered them to the hand of Sheshbazzar-Daniel, who was called by that name.
[as translated,] and brought them.
[as translated,] had taken them out.
for he was a prince and a governor and was called by the name governor.
And so did Cyrus say to Sheshbazzar, “Take these vessels and bring them down into the Temple that is in Jerusalem, and the House of the Holy One, blessed be He, shall be built on its place.”
[as translated,] then.
Aram. דֵּ, came and built the walls of the House of the Holy One, blessed be He, that is in Jerusalem, and from then until now, the House has been built, but the building has not been completed.
And now, if it pleases the king, let the matter be known and searched out in the king’s archives, which is located in Babylon.
whether this incident is so, that permission was issued by Cyrus to build this House, which is in Jerusalem.

text.title: and the will of the king:

pasuk.text: And the will of the king concerning this he shall send to us.
Aram. עֲלֶינָא, lit. on us. Until here is the text of the letter that Tattenai and Shethar- bozenai sent.
then when the letter reached Darius’s hand.
The king ordered the matter.
They searched in the library where the archives were stored in Babylon.

text.title: And there was found in a pouch:

pasuk.text: And a text of one scroll was found there in an אַחְמְתָא. So did the interpreters interpret, that it is a receptacle made for letters, written sheets and books, and they established it from the root of (Gen. 21:14): “a skin of water (וְחֵמַת מַיִם) ,” and the “aleph” in the word is not a radical, like the rest of the Aramaic language.
in that citadel that was in the province of Media.
and so was written therein its memorandum.

text.title: the House of God in Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: regarding the House of God in Jerusalem; what should be with it?“The House should be built.”

text.title: a place where they offer up sacrifices:

pasuk.text: which is a place where they offer up sacrifices.

text.title: and its walls should be founded:

pasuk.text: Aram. וְאֻשּׁוֹהִי. And its walls should be founded, like (4: 12): “and its walls (וְאֻשַּׁיָא) they have joined.”
the height of the House was sixty cubits, and sixty cubits was its width.
Aram. נִדְבָּכִין, an expression for walls. The walls were of marble.
Aram. גְּלָל (marmre in Old French).
and a wall of new wood from within, in the manner of the building of the Temple that Solomon built.
And the expenditures for the needs of the House and for the other matters pertaining to the House shall be given them from the royal palace.
and also the sacred vessels of the House of God, of gold and silver, which Nebuchadnezzar took out of the Temple in Jerusalem and brought to Babylon.
[as translated,] let them be given over.
which he brought.
Let all this work be brought to the Temple that is in Jerusalem, to its place.
And it shall be deposited in the House of the Holy One, blessed be He.
This is the reply with which Darius answered Tattenai and Shethar-Bozenai.

text.title: who are on the other side of the river:

pasuk.text: to the side of the land of Israel, which is the other side of the river to those in Babylon
Distance yourselves from the building of the Temple, so that you do not disturb the workers.
[as translated,] this.
The rulers of the Jews shall do this thing.

text.title: and to the elders of the Jews:

pasuk.text: And to the elders of the Jews I command.
[as translated,] this House of God.

text.title: And from me shall be issued an order:

pasuk.text: And from me this command will go forth.
regarding that building, the work that you shall do with these elders of the Jews to build the House of the Holy One, blessed be He.
And from the king’s property they shall make ths building.

text.title: from the taxes of the other side of the river:

pasuk.text: from the taxes of the other side of the river, which belong to the king.
Aram. מִדַּת, tax, like (4:13): “the king’s due (מִנְדָּה), the head tax, or the meal tax.”
Aram. אָסְפַּרְנָא. The building shall quickly be built; esploytosemant in Old French.
The expenses shall be given to these men so that they should not idle from their work.
and what they are concerned about.
young bulls, rams and lambs for burnt offerings to the God of heaven.
for fine flour.
for sacrifices.
for libations.
for the meal-offerings. When the priests who are in Jerusalem will say [what they need], that shall be given to them the requirements of each day on its day.
Aram. דִּי לָא שָּׁלוּ (son destorber in Old French).
in order that they should offer up pleasing sacrificing to the God of the heavens, and that they should pray for the life of the king and his children.

text.title: And an order is issued by me:

pasuk.text: And a command is issued by me, along with the issue of a word regarding any person who disobeys this word.
Aram. יִתְנְסַח. The beams of his house shall be destroyed. יִתְנְסַח is like (Deut. 28:63): “and you shall be uprooted (וְנִסַחְתֶּם) from the land.”

text.title: and a gallows upon which to place him:

pasuk.text: And a gallows upon which to hang him shall be [raised up] high, so that he be hanged upon the gallows.

text.title: and his house shall be made a dungheap:

pasuk.text: and his house shall be made a dungheap because of this. נְוָלוּ connotes filth and excrement.

text.title: And God, Who caused His name to rest there:

pasuk.text: [as translated,] and God, Who caused His name to rest there.
will cast down and destroy any such king and any such people that will stretch forth a hand to lay waste and destroy His house that is in Jerusalem.
I have issued a command concerning this matter, that the building be constructed swiftly. Until here is Darius’s reply.
[as translated,] as was said.
[as translated,] acted swiftly.

text.title: And the elders of the Jews:

pasuk.text: And the elders of the Jews were building and succeeding in their work, according to the prophecy of Haggai and Zechariah, and they built and founded the building by the command of the God of Israel and by the authorization of Cyrus, the first king of Persia, in whose days the laying of the foundation was commenced, and by the authorization of this Darius, the king of Persia.
He is Darius, but he was called Artaxerxes because of the province and the kingdom, for all kings of Persia were thus named just as all the kings of Egypt were called Pharaoh.

text.title: And the completion of this House:

pasuk.text: And the end of the completion of this House was until the third day of the month of Adar, which is the sixth year of King Darius; hence the building of the House took four years.

text.title: And they offered up for the dedication:

pasuk.text: They offered up for the dedication of this House these sacrifices, and it was a temporary ruling.

text.title: Now they set up the priests in their divisions:

pasuk.text: for the priests were divided in their service and the Levites in their watches.
Now Israel made the Passover offering on this fourteenth of Nissan, which followed this Adar, when the building was completed.
Heb. וְלָהֶם, lit. and for them, and for themselves.
They are the proselytes, who were separated from the defilement of the nations to cleave to Israel.

text.title: and turned the heart of the king of Assyria toward them:

pasuk.text: And the Holy One, blessed be He, turned the heart of the king of Assyria toward the Israelites who were dwelling under his dominion in the land of Assyria, to strengthen them and to assist in the work of the building.
of the building of the House.
That is Darius.
[i.e., King] Darius.

text.title: according to the command of the Lord his God upon him:

pasuk.text: as the Holy One, blessed be He, had commanded him. This verse is transposed [its meaning being]: and the King granted him his entire request, according to the command of the Lord upon him. And our Rabbis said (Meg. 15a) that Ezra and Malachi were one and the same.
That is a year after the completion of the Temple.
That is Darius.
i.e., the month of Av, for the first of the month of Nissan was the beginning of their ascent from Babylon, and on the first of the month of Av they arrived in Jerusalem.

text.title: was the commencement of the ascent:

pasuk.text: the foundation of the commencement of the ascent.

text.title: according to the… hand of his God:

pasuk.text: as the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, caused him to succeed, for His hand was good upon him to make him succeed in his way.
Therefore, he went and prospered in his way, because Ezra prepared his heart, etc. He gives a reason for his words.

text.title: And this is the interpretation of the writ:

pasuk.text: Heb. הַכְּתָב פַתְשֶּׁגֶן.
and His statutes that He commanded Israel to keep.
He has mastered it in his hand.
[as translated,] the Book of Law.

text.title: An order is issued by me:

pasuk.text: The authorization emanates from me that whoever of Israel, of the priests, or of the Levites, whose heart prompts him to go to Jerusalem, may go with you.
Because of this, you are sent from the king and his seven advisors who saw the king’s face.
and his seven advisors; they are the seven who see the king’s face.
An order to seek and to search out the Jews who are in Jerusalem, to see whether they are engaged in the Torah of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is in your hand.
and to bring the silver and gold of the king and his advisors that they donated to the God of Israel, to maintain His House, Whose habitation and House are in Jerusalem.

text.title: And all the silver and gold:

pasuk.text: and all the silver and gold that you will find in the province of Babylon, together with the donations of the people and the priests that they will donate to the House of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is in Jerusalem; you shall take everything to Jerusalem.

And because of this, because it is for the service of the Sanctuary, you shall quickly purchase with this money cattle, rams and lambs; sacrifices, meal-offerings, and libations, and you shall offer them up on the altar of the Holy One, blessed be He.
And what pleases you and your brethren (to do) with the rest of the silver and the gold, according to the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, you shall do.
And the vessels that are given to you for the service of the Holy One, blessed be He, give in their entirety before the Holy One, blessed be He, in Jerusalem.

text.title: And the rest of the necessities:

pasuk.text: and the rest of the necessities that you will require for the House of the Holy One, blessed be He, to purchase, for which you will have to give the money; you shall give from the royal treasury.

And from me-I, King Darius-is issued a command and an authorization to all the treasurers who are on the other side of the river of the side of Israel, who receive my taxes from the nations, that anything that Ezra the priest, the scholar of the Law of the Holy One, blessed be He, requests of you, shall be performed quickly. They should not delay his request up to a hundred talents of silver, with which to purchase sacrifices, and a hundred kors of wheat for meal-offerings, and up to a hundred measures of wine for the libations, and a hundred measures of oil to mingle the meal-offerings, and salt for the sacrifices, according to the matter that is stated (Lev. 2:13): “And every meal-offering you shall salt with salt.”
And salt, regarding which no measure is written, they shall give according to how much is needed.
Whatever is with the authorization of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His command, shall be done with alacrity, with the seal of the king for the House of the Holy One, blessed be He.
Aram. אַדְרַזְדָּא, seal in Arabic.
For why should there be wrath against the realm of the king and his sons? Therefore, the treasurers shall provide all the needs of the House.

text.title: And we are making known to you:

pasuk.text: And we are making known to you that [over] all the priests, the Levites, the musicians, the gatekeepers, and the Nethinites, who are wood cutters and water drawers for the altar, and those who serve in this House of the Holy One, no man shall be empowered over them to levy upon them any tribute or head tax, but they shall be free from the service of the king.

text.title: And you, Ezra, according to the wisdom of your God, which is in your hand:

pasuk.text: and you, Ezra, according to the wisdom of your God, which is in your hand [and which is] greater than that of the judges and the magistrates who judge all the people beyond the river to the side of Israel, the people knowledgeable in the Torah.
and the judge who does not know how to judge, inform him of the judgment that he should execute it.
and whoever does not fulfill the law of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the law of the king promptly, viz. that he delays the law and the judgment.
The judgment shall be inflicted upon him, upon the one who obstructs justice.
[as translated,] whether to be executed.
whether to uproot him from the world, him, his offspring and his family (לִשְּׁרשִׁי is desraziner in Old French, to uproot).
to be punished with money.

or to torture him with tortures. Until here is the writ of the letter that King Darius gave to Ezra the scribe in order that he convey it to Jerusalem to show it to the priests and the Levites and the king’s treasurers, in order that they persist in performing the commandments and worshiping the Lord in the Temple and keeping the Torah properly.
Ezra wrote this in his Book when he gave thanks to the Holy One, blessed be He.
They are his seven advisers mentioned above (verse 14).

text.title: according to the hand of the Lord my God upon me:

pasuk.text: as the help of the Holy One, blessed be He, was upon me; and I gathered from the Israelites remaining in Babylon the chiefs of the fathers’ houses and the great men to ascend with me from Babylon.

text.title: And these are the heads of their fathers’ houses:

pasuk.text: of the immigrants.
and their lineage to which they attributed their descent.
He is Darius.

text.title: Of the sons of Shechaniah, of the sons of Parosh:

pasuk.text: That is one family, and Zechariah was the head of the family.
With his lineage, the males of his family traced their lineage.
That was his name.
who were the last ones to go after Ezra.
Heb. הַבָּא אֶל הַנָהָר, lit. to the coming river.
to that river.
and we were camping there.
I directed my attention to survey the people who had gathered with me.

text.title: And I sent to Eliezer… the heads:

pasuk.text: the great men.
Heb. מְבִינִים, lit. understanding. They were wise men.
I sent them and commanded them to speak to Iddo, who was the greatest and most esteemed in Casiphia.
Heb. עַל אִדוֹ, lit. about Iddo.

text.title: and I put… into their mouth:

pasuk.text: I put into their mouth words to speak as my emissary to Iddo and his brother, who were placed and settled in Casiphia, to bring us servants to serve in the Temple.
the name of a place in Babylon.
the name of a man.
Heb. הַנְתִינִים, like הַנְתוּנִים, those who were settled. Therefore, it is written with a “vav.”

text.title: according to the hand of our God:

pasuk.text: just as the success of the Holy One, blessed be He, was upon us.
a wise man.
All these were Levites.
And of the slaves, the Nethnites that King David had appointed, and the chefs of Israel ascended with them.
Heb. לְהִתְעַנוֹת to fast.
that the Omnipresent lead us in peace.
For I was ashamed of the king, and I did not wish to request of him chariots and horsemen in order to guide us.
For we had already said to King Darius that the Holy One, blessed be He, benefits those who seek Him and pours out His wrath and His anger upon those who forsake Him.
for we arrived safely in Jerusalem.
And when I was there by the river Ahava, I separated some of the chiefs of the priests and weighed out the silver and the gold for them to deposit into the treasuries of the House of the Lord.
which those living in Babylon had offered.

text.title: and one hundred silver vessels by talents:

pasuk.text: one talent for each vessel.
bowls for sprinkling [the blood of the sacrifices].
a type of coin. There were one thousand darics in these twenty sprinkling bowls of gold.
of golden copper (or) a type of copper coin.
Heb. טוֹבָה, the feminine form, modifying copper (נְחֹשֶּׁת).
two vessels.
Heb. חֲמוּדוֹת כַּזָהָב. He calls the vessels חֲמוּדוֹת in the feminine form.
to these chiefs of the priests.

text.title: the chambers of the House of the Lord:

pasuk.text: in order to deposit them in the chambers of the Temple.

text.title: on the twelfth of the first month:

pasuk.text: on the twelfth of Nissan

text.title: the hand of our God was upon us:

pasuk.text: to cause us to succeed in the way that we traversed.
The number of the vessels and their weights was the same when they received them as when they itemized them.

text.title: Those coming from captivity, the people of the exile:

pasuk.text: those who came with Ezra.
all were burnt offerings, and it was a temporary ruling.

text.title: And they gave the king’s decrees:

pasuk.text: These returnees from exile related King Darius’s mandate to the officers of the king, those who see his face.
Heb. וּפַחֲווֹת, like וְפַחוֹת.
those on the side of the land of Israel, who are considered as being beyond the river of the inhabitants of Babylon.
They were exalting and assisting.
these incidents that related the kings’ decrees.
of Israel.
And so they said to me.
for they commenced to deal treacherously by intermarrying with the peoples of the lands.
out of the great pain due to this treachery. bewildered Heb. מְשּׁוֹמֵם miserable and bewildered, like (Ez. 3:15): “… seven days bewildered among them.”
for I had not eaten on that day.

Heb. נִתַּנוּ, like נִתַּנְנוּ. The “dagesh” in the “nun” is instead of another “nun,” like (II Chron. 14:10): “for we rely (תִשְּׁעַנוּ) on You,” like נִשְּׁעַנְנוּ. (Gen. 34:16): “… then we will give (וְנָתַנוּ) our daughters,” like וְנָתַנְנוּ.
as appears this day, for the Ten Tribes have already been exiled, and many of the exiles still remain in Babylon.

text.title: And now, for a short moment:

pasuk.text: temporarily.
Heb. תְּחִנָה, like חֲנִינָה

text.title: and to give us a peg:

pasuk.text: to establish us in the land of Israel.
יָתֵד, like (Isa. 22:23): “And I will thrust him like a peg (יָתֵד) in a sure place.”
[as translated,] a little life.
to Darius, king of Persia.
Heb. לֹא עֲזָבָנוּ, a combination of לֹא עָזַב אוֹתָנוּ.
Heb. וַיַט, an expression of the causative, like מַטֶה. He extended His loving-kindness upon us.
for they had created a fence to keep His commandments.
Heb. נִדָה, unclean and repulsive.

text.title: and you shall cause… to inherit:

pasuk.text: You shall give the land to your children as an inheritance to eternity.

text.title: And after all that has come upon us:

pasuk.text: after all the calamity that has befallen us because of our evil deeds.

You have held back from our iniquities until below them [i.e., less than them], for our iniquity was lessened by the expiation effected by our exile. We may also interpret it in this manner: You held Yourself back from collecting from us all our iniquity, and You collected from us below [less than] the iniquities, and You requited us according to all our sins.
Heb. הֲנָשּׁוּב, if we return.

text.title: will You not be wroth with us:

pasuk.text: a wonder with an affirmative answer.
lit. for there is nothing; i.e., we do not have the power of good deeds to stand and exist before You, because of this transgression.
Heb. בּכֶה, like בֶּכִי.
And we took them in.
There is hope for Israel concerning this, for they can cast out their foreign wives and their offspring and cast out all the children born from these foreign wives.

text.title: by the counsel of the Lord:

pasuk.text: by the counsel and the will of the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: and those who hasten to [perform] the commandment of our God:

pasuk.text: and the God-fearers, they shall cast them out.

text.title: and according to the Law it shall be done:

pasuk.text: he who performs this act, who will cast out his gentile wife and children.
to agree with you.
Heb. קוֹל, lit. a voice, an announcement.
at the end of three days.
That is the month of Kislev.
They were afraid over the matter. They were afraid of the stumbling block of this transgression.
And because of the rains that were falling upon them there, they were shivering and miserable.
Heb. תּוֹדָה, [which, in this case, means] וִדּוּי, confession.

text.title: and it is the rainy season:

pasuk.text: for the rains are falling upon us.
And this separation from sin cannot be executed so quickly.
Heb. לְכָל הַקָהָל
Heb. הַהשִּׁיב equivalent to אֲשֶּׁר הוֹשִּׁיב.
until the burning anger of the Holy One, blessed be He, returns from upon us.
to argue concerning this matter.
strengthened their hands.
Heb. לְדַרְיוֹשּׁ, like לִדְרוֹשּׁ.
And they completed the rectification of the matter of the men who had brought in heathen wives, for they cast them out.
until the first day of Nissan.
Heb. וַיִתְּנוּ יָדָם, lit. and they gave their hand, their advice, like (II Sam. 14:19): “Behold Joab’s advice (יַד יוֹאָב) is with you in all this (sic).”
This was a temporary ruling.

text.title: And of the sons of Immer:

pasuk.text: All these are priests until (verse 23): “And of the Levites, etc.”

text.title: and some of them had wives by whom they had children:

pasuk.text: And some of them had heathen wives by whom they had children. They cast out all of them, both the wives and the children.
